text:
Name: Sam H. McWilliams

Address: 260 Athabasca St., Moose Jaw

Dec 9th 1955

Dear Sir,

Please send questionnaire on "What did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" I remember getting my last copy of Sask Hist. I consider myself an Old Timer arrived in Moose Jaw 1884. Was at the first Agricultural Show held in Moose Jaw 1884. We lived on very coarse fare, fish caught in spring, salted enough to last all summer, Jack rabbit of wild game. Salt Side Bacon settlers called it Rattle Snake pork. More later when I have more.

S. H. McWilliams

Do you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, some remember as a boy of 10 years pounding wheel on a smooth flat rock with a hammer to make porridge for the family not once but many times. I will attach a letter to this report wheel I can relate some early experiences you can understand or cannot answer straight off. Need questions, my eyes a small tear from crying at that time.
260 Athabasca St.
Moose Jaw
Dec 9th 1950

Dear Sir,

Please send questionnaire on What did Western Canadian Pioneer Eat.

I don't remember getting my last copy of Sask History.

I consider myself an Old Timer arrived in Moose Jaw 1884. Was at the first Agricultural Show held in Moose Jaw 1884.

We lived on very coarse fare, fish caught in spring salted enough to last all summer. Jackrabbits of wild game. Salt Side Bacon. Settlers called it rattle snake pork.

More later when I hear from you.

S. H. McWilliam
Dear Sir,

Please send Mr. Williamson an invitation to attend the Centennial Gathering of the Descendants of Jacob H. Williams.

I would like to invite you to attend the first Agricultural Show held in Monroe County in 1884. We had a wonderful time, and I believe it was a great success.

More later when I have more news.

Yours sincerely,
S. H. Me William
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Samuel H. McWilliams
Address: 260 Athabasca St., Moose Jaw
Birthplace: Manitoba, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? Sept. 1884
   Where did you set up housekeeping?
   Where had you been living before that? Manitoba, Ont.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 8
   How far was it to your nearest store? 13 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually once a month
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Tea, Sugar, Beans, Oatmeal, flour, bread, Butter, milk, eggs purchased

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (not remembered)
   No mills in the neighborhood came from Ontario
   In what quantities did you buy it? 95 lbs. per bag
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
   How much did you use of other flour? Not a great deal
   Whole wheat flour? Some
   Was flour milled locally? No, far away
   What year? 1884 or 1885
   That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? (not recalled)
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes, Whole wheat? Some, Farina? No
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, some, Remember as a boy of 13 years pounding wheel on a smooth
   How did you grind it? (not recalled)
   I let gook with a hammer to make porridge for the family first once but many times I will attach a letter to the report where I can state some early experiences
   You can understand if cannot answer several of these questions, my being at that time
McWilliams, Sam H.,
260 Athabasca St. W.,
Moose Jaw.

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Board, Box 109, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Samuel McWilliams
Address: 260 Athabasca St. Moose Jaw
Birthplace: British Columbia
Date: Sept. 1854

1. How did you start homesteading?
There had you been living before that?
For how many years did you live there?
How far was it to your nearest store?
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in these earliest years?

Tea, salt, flour, sugar, butter, milk, eggs, canned goods, canned meat.

2. Future of the Homestead
In what quantities did you use?
That was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour in 1854.
How much did you use of each kind?
Was flour milled locally?
Was the price for a twenty pound bar of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Corn meal, flour, whole wheat, etc.

Did you trial your own wheat for porting?
How did you find it?
Let me know what a hearty meal would consist of.
Would you like some additional information about your experiences?
If so, please let me know.
WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN WOMEN EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: H.M. Williams
Address: 260 Athabasca Ave, Moose Jaw
Birthplace: Qu'Appelle, Sask.

1. INTERESTING EVENTS
   What was your mother who passed away about 1920?
   What year did you start housekeeping? Sept. 1884
   Where did you set up housekeeping?
   Where had you been living before that? Moose Jaw
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 8
   How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually once a month
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years?
   Tea, sugar, beans, oatmeal, flour, bread, butter, until new husband

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Don't remember
   No mill in the west, flour came from Ontario
   In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb bag
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.50
   How much did you use Graham flour? Not a great deal
   Whole wheat flour? Some
   Was flour milled locally? No, far away
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 10¢ or 15¢
   What other grain products did you use? Oats
   Cornmeal? Yes, some, whole wheat? Some, parina? No
   Other?

   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, some, remember as a boy of 10 years pounding wheel on a smooth flat rock with a hammer to make porridge for the family just once but many times I will have a letter to this effect when I can relate some early experiences
   You can understand I cannot answer all of these questions, my spring is small by far buying at that time
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? 
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? 
Butter? 
Did you make butter? 
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? 
How did you get fresh meat? 
How often did you get fresh meat? 
How did you preserve meat? 
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? 

If so, what was it organized? 
Did you use game? 
For how long? 
What fish did you catch? 
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? 

Use preparation for use.

Turnips No Beets No

Peas? Yes Corn? No Beans? No Saskatoons? No

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1885

To what extent?
Did you make your own vinegar? Mother always did

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) from Moose Jaw River North of Dawson.

How far was this water from your home? One mile.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel on street.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

The writer has moved since he had spring water when living near Calumet 18 miles S.E. of Moose Jaw. Had deep well for water supply.

18. **SHOPPINGS AND GROCERIES**

*Note any changes which you recall in the packaging and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).* 

Green tea was ground. Brown sugar called "Brown Sugar" for 25¢. In fact, it was just as good as the common kind. Most all the same packages were resealed. Bread was $4.25 to $6.00 loaves & wrapped out to customers. This held food all through the eighties.

---

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast:** Simulated oatmeal, salt bacon, or salt fish, tea or coffee potatoes, bread

**Dinner:** Salt bacon, potato, rice, pudding, or dish prunes or dried apples. No old friend string or string beans with celery.

**Supper:** Same as dinner.

---

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

---

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

---

20. How did you get along with your neighbors when you lived there?

---

21. What was the nearest town?
18. **SNAPSHOTS AND OUTLINES**

One day in our lives which you recall in the strangest and evocative way. You can remember, give the name and list all the things there possible.

---

19. **What did you serve your first Christmas dinner?** List these presents and give their value.

---

20. **Have you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two locally purchased foods?** Give details.

---

21. **Was there any other notable event over the past year?** Write about it.

---

22. **McWilliams, Samuel Henry**
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

gives a bachelor in a year so cannot proceed on different methods of cooking

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I cannot remember any changes to seeds from the early days until sometime in the 1900s hundreds.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above; quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the spring of 1856 Father rented a farm some miles east of Moose Jaw, only south of the Moose Jaw River. Each in the spring had to get saltage of 13. He took salt sufficient to make about three buckets. Some buckets was not in one place mixed with water, narrow mouthed jars trying to get water out of the water they had to wash in these jugs. Out of the water they had to wash in these jugs in front of slender willows tied on the inside of a barrel made of the side of the old wine keg net with a cone inside so fish could not get out again. It had been made Indians. Women together had placed it in the water where it was shallow inside he built a wall of stone on each side of the net. The next morning it was packed full 3 or 4 barrels full each morning it was packed full for summer use. Each morning it was cleaned & salted for summer use. All were they used cleaned & salted for summer use. They used them in turn did the same thing until all were used.
21. Then did you begin to rely on oral and written records (giving only details and dates of purchase) instead of documents? If so, how many years did you keep these records?

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying grocerias, including types of grocerias purchased, prices paid, and any other details.

---

From the early days until sometime in the 1900s, he had...
had purchased a hall on two of Brixton's farms near the town of Brixton. The farms were called "The Shrewsbury" and "The Shrewsbury Hall." The farms were owned by Mr. and Mrs. Smith.

Mr. Smith was very kind and generous. He always invited us to his house for dinner. We would spend our afternoons there playing games and talking about our lives.

One day, we went to visit Mr. Smith at his farm. We walked through the fields and admired the beautiful scenery. Mr. Smith showed us around his farm and explained how he grew his crops.

We spent the afternoon enjoying each other's company and learning about farming. It was a wonderful day and we left feeling grateful for the opportunity to spend time with such a kind and generous man.

P.S. If you ever need help, just give me a call early morning.
had purchased a well on two acres of Brazil pasture land from Mr. Brown. The purchase included a small house and a barn. The new owner was very pleased with the property.

The barn was in good condition and had been recently painted. It was located near the main road and was easily visible from a distance.

The new owner decided to rent out the barn to a local farmer who needed storage space for his equipment. The rent would be $50 per month, payable in advance.

The farmer agreed to the terms and signed the lease. He was grateful for the opportunity to rent such a large and well-maintained building.

The new owner also purchased a small plot of land next to the barn. He planned to plant vegetables and keep a few chickens there.

The new owner was very pleased with his purchase and looked forward to making the most of his new property.
I purchased a lot or two of Bragg's milk and made cheese. He also gave me a cow. The cheese was very good.

We also had a horse. We made a herd of cattle that were my job. We kept them in the barnyard. We would milk them twice a day.

Well, the whole summer was very busy and we worked hard. We had a good harvest.

With milk and cheese, we lived off the land.

Hoping this message is of some use to you.

[Signature]
Jennings Williams

P.S. If any of your stuff called upon some early morning, I may be able to give a little more.
Hoping Christmas be of Some merit to you

& Remain & Yours Truly

Sam H. Breckinridge

P.S. If one of your 35¢s could come from some time I may be able to give a little sooner early Monday
